content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool, little clash.
Like that one.
javascript:
a=[...Array(5)].map(readline);
[x,y]=a[0].match(/\d+/g)
k=a[4].indexOf('A')
print(x*k==y*(a[3].length-k-1)?1:0)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I tested it and everything works fine. Really nice puzzle. It is really amazing and could be even better when the weights are not always at the extremities. Here is my Ruby solution. 
s,t,t,q,f=`dd`.split"
"
r,t=s.scan(/\d+/).map &:to_i
g=f.index'A'
p r*g==t*(q.size-g-1)?1:0

@AndreMarasca, really nice one. Just a small suggestion. In all the test cases and validators, both the weights are at the extremes. Only the fulcrum's position changes. So, most of them will not consider the middle two lines. They will assume the indices to be 0 and -1 (if the language supports negative indexing). So, making the user read the 3rd line from top (1-based indexing)  would be nice. Else it'd just remain redundant. But I really appreciate this. Really different and very nice. Thoughtful puzzle.

Some test cases shall be like this
         14kg                          9kg
         |                                 |
         V                                 V
________________________________________________________
                                                            A



                13kg                              7 kg
                 |                                    |
                 V                                    V
__________________________________________________
                           A


54kg36kg
|        |
V        V
_____________________________________________________________
                                                                     A


etc.

Nice clash!
Just a small thing, the statement has
 w1 * d1 == w2 ** d2
Other than the extra *, everything looks great.

Might be my eyes;  the statement might be better with the equation set out differently or use a different variable for the distance from fulcrum, say d instead of l? e.g.

When (w1 x d1) equals (w2 x d2) the seesaw is balanced.

Might be good to have a zero weight test case and a long balance with a balanced result? Does the seesaw weigh anything as this would affect the result?

Hope this is constructive, seems a nice idea.
You are right, the seesaw has no weight of its own, it is not to change the result
Oh. I hadn't seen my typo. Thank you very much Sahilrox
So, I put the weights on the ends to simplify the problem. Even as simple as it is, I believe that many will not be able to solve it.
It is OK Andre. It is really nice though :)
